title: Getting Started with Quarto
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of the session, participants will be able to:

Describe how Quarto can enhance transparency in scientific and technical publishing.
Use RStudio to combine narrative text, R code, mathematical formulas, and citations within Quarto to produce polished and verifiable research documents.
Publish Quarto documents into the following format: static HTML document, Word, PDF and RevealJS presentation to cater to different publication and presentation needs.
Use Quarto Pub or GitHub Pages to create websites to communicate their research findings to a wider audience.

title: Getting Started with Quarto
text:
Literate Programming

“Let us change our traditional attitude to the construction of programs: Instead of imagining that our main task is to instruct a computer what to do, let us concentrate rather on explaining to human beings what we want a computer to do.”
– Donald Knuth, 1984

Essentially, literate programming is about:

Creating code that is not only executable but also readable and understandable by humans
Weaving code and documentation in a single document, emphasizing human-readable explanation alongside executable code

title: Getting Started with Quarto
text:
Research Transparency & Reproducibility

Enables researcher to provide clear, detailed descriptions of their methodologies, algorithms, and computational processes.
This integration ensures that the logic and rationale behind each part of the code are explicitly documented, making it easier for others to follow, reproduce, and validate the research.
Reduces ambiguities and potential misinterpretations, fostering a more robust and transparent scientific discourse.

In Quarto, this is enabled through code chunks - more details about this on the next session

section: Executable Python code blocks in Quarto
text:
Executable Python code blocks in Quarto

Install the reticulate package to seamlessly integrate Python code chunks in Quarto install.packages("reticulate")
When you use a Python chunk in a Quarto document, knitr uses reticulate to execute the Python code



Note: Knitr is a dynamic report generation engine for R that executes code chunks embedded in documents, integrating the results seamlessly into the output, thus enabling reproducible research and literate programming.

title: Getting Started with Quarto
text:
What is YAML?


Quarto documents begin with YAML (YAML Ain’t Markup Language) headers
YAML specify document metadata and control settings which influences document rendering and final output in many different ways:

Title, author, date
Output format (HTML, PDF, Word, etc.)
Table of contents settings
Bibliography and citation style
And more!

title: Getting Started with Quarto
text:
Markdown and R Markdown

Markdown is the underlying document syntax for Quarto and R Markdown
lightweight markup language, which uses plain text with simple syntax for easy text formatting
widely used for documentation, README files and web content
RMarkdown is an extension of Markdown, developed by RStudio, which allows embedding of R code chunks within Markdown documents

section: Adding code chunks to your document
text:
Adding code chunks to your document
Use three backticks (now this is getting confusing) to create a fenced code block in your Quarto document
```
## You may write some code (non executable) here
```

Fenced code block is helpful to show multiple lines of code
everything inside the ‘fences’ is treated literally as code or plain text, and not processed by Quarto

title: Getting Started with Quarto
text:

title: Getting Started with Quarto
text:
Rendering
Besides rendering with the RStudio button, you may also render via:

Terminal or system shell:

quarto render document.qmd # defaults to html
quarto render document.qmd --to pdf
quarto render document.qmd --to docx

R console using quarto R package

library(quarto)
quarto_render("document.qmd") # defaults to html
quarto_render("document.qmd", output_format = "pdf")

Figures: Display size

Change display size by adding width and height attributes:
![Elephant](elephant.png){width=300}
Default units are pixels. You can also specify sizes using a percentage:

Note


If only width or height is specified, the other will be calculated automatically




this is 80% of the container size, responsive design when the content area may change, consistent sizing across different devices, screen sizes and formats

title: Try-it-together: Getting Started with Quarto for Academic Writing
text:
This workshop is Part 1 of SMU Researcher Club’s Try-it-together Quarto Series:

Part 1: Try-it-together: Getting Started with Quarto for Academic Writing on 15 Oct, 2024
Part 2: Try-it-together: Generate Reports and Presentation with Quarto on 22 Oct, 2024
Part 3: Try-it-together: Building Your Research Website - From Quarto to the Web on 29 Oct, 2024

In academic research, the journey from raw data to published findings often lacks transparency, posing significant challenges to reproducibility and trust in scientific research. This situation highlights the need for enhanced transparency and traceability within research methodologies.
The primary objective of this 3-part course is to equip participants with the necessary skills to use Quarto and RStudio to publish research in a transparent and reproducible way. These tools enable an integrated research workflow encompassing data cleaning, analysis, visualization, and publishing, producing verifiable research outputs and artifacts. They facilitate validation and replication of research findings, thereby enhancing the integrity and credibility of published work.
Quarto, an open-source scientific publishing system, allows researchers to weave together narrative text, code, mathematical formulas (using LATeX), and even citations to produce elegantly formatted output as documents, web pages, blog posts, books and other formats to cater to diverse publishing needs. While Quarto is also compatible with Python and Julia, the course will predominantly focus on its application in R programming.

title: Try-it-together: Getting Started with Quarto for Academic Writing
text:
Lesson Objectives

Understand the fundamental concepts of Quarto, including its role in promoting transparency and reproducibility in academic writing.
Learn how to navigate the Quarto interface within RStudio, focusing on the basics of Markdown for structuring academic documents.
Gain hands-on experience in creating simple Quarto documents by integrating narrative text, code, figures, and tables.







Note



Prior experience with R is highly recommended for this course.

title: Try-it-together: Getting Started with Quarto for Academic Writing
text:
Pre-session Preparation
Please ensure that you have completed the following activities before the workshop begin:

Download and install the latest version of R
Download and install the latest version of RStudio
Download and install the latest version of Quarto

Although Quarto comes bundled with RStudio, it is often a few versions behind. The bundled version is version 1.22, while the latest version is on 1.5.55

Download the hands-on exercises, which will be copied into your project folder during the lesson.
Install these R packages. Copy the following code and paste it in the Console tab (left side pane of RStudio), and then press Enter.
install.packages(c( "tidyverse", "gt", "rmarkdown", "gtsummary", "palmerpenguins"))
You’re ready to go! You can close Rstudio for now and see you soon!
